Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5395 - Strategies for Growth","description":"

This elective course on Strategies for Growth is a follow-up course to the core Strategy course offered at full time MBA program. Growth is possibly the most important concern of a firm after survival and the ability to manage growth has become a priority in the corporate agenda for sustaining competitive advantage. Strategies for Growth will provide students with an understanding of how to think strategically for growth. The course is structured around different growth strategies available to managers, including internal research and development, corporate venturing programs and corporate venture capital, joint ventures, mergers and acquisitions, and globalisation.

contentlets.description: This elective course on Strategies for Growth is a follow-up course to the core Strategy course offered at full time MBA program. Growth is possibly the most important concern of a firm after survival and the ability to manage growth has become a priority in the corporate agenda for sustaining competitive advantage. Strategies for Growth will provide students with an understanding of how to think strategically for growth. The course is structured around different growth strategies available to managers, including internal research and development, corporate venturing programs and corporate venture capital, joint ventures, mergers and acquisitions, and globalisation.
contentlets.title: Strategies for Growth

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5521 - Financial Strategy","description":"

The focus of the course is on corporate financing: that is, how organisations create and use strategies in the financial markets to obtain funding for their activities, how they structure the contracts for the supply of capital, and how they link these to internal contracts with assets within the organisation. Additionally, we will explore the application of corporate finance theory in the business environment.

In Weeks 1 to 6, students will prepare oral analyses of a set of cases or exercises provided by the facilitator.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"332718021b92f450d5fb0fabdc4bcb49","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"332718021b92f450d5fb0fabdc4bcb4a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"332718021b92f450d5fb0fabdc4bcb4b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3b2718021b92f450d5fb0fabdc4bcb48","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3b2718021b92f450d5fb0fabdc4bcb49","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3b2718021b92f450d5fb0fabdc4bcb4a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"3f2718021b92f450d5fb0fabdc4bcb47","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"332718021b92f450d5fb0fabdc4bcb4d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Mid-session Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

A mid-session quiz assessment will be assigned around weeks 3-4. Further details will be provided at the commencement of the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"332718021b92f450d5fb0fabdc4bcb49","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3b2718021b92f450d5fb0fabdc4bcb48","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3b2718021b92f450d5fb0fabdc4bcb4a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bb2718021b92f450d5fb0fabdc4bcb63","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Group Case Development Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

The Case Development provides you with the opportunity to explore in depth a particular area of the course by collating materials for, and creating a first write-up of, a real-world case designed to show a particular model or process in Financial Strategy. The case could be used in an MBA course in Financial Strategy for students with a good understanding of basic finance theory and some applications. The work is done in a self-selected group, so students are given a clear opportunity to share their learning, and learn from others, about the area. This exercise is intended to allow students to assess their engagement with the disciplinary knowledge and their critical and analytical thinking in a team environment.

Additionally, we will explore the application of corporate finance theory in the business environment.

Acquisitions","description":"

The objective of this course is to introduce students to Mergers and Acquisitions (M&A) and the requisite knowledge for the development and execution of corporate transactions particularly within equity capital markets. Typical transactions include Takeovers, Acquisitions, Divestments, Initial Public Offerings and Private Equity. Each of these types of transactions will be addressed within the course.


Students will utilise common corporate finance tools and knowledge as applied within the context of considering, developing and executing M&A transactions. Participants will apply insights and skills taken from previous courses in finance.


The course includes negotiation within the context of M&A.


Case studies are used extensively throughout the course? including the use of current or recent transactions involving listed companies.


The course is a mixture of presentations, class discussions, case studies and group exercises all with an emphasis on the practical applications of corporate finance skills and knowledge within the context of M&A.

contentlets.description:
The objective of this course is to introduce students to Mergers and Acquisitions (M&A) and the requisite knowledge for the development and execution of corporate transactions particularly within equity capital markets. Typical transactions include Takeovers, Acquisitions, Divestments, Initial Public Offerings and Private Equity. Each of these types of transactions will be addressed within the course.

Students will utilise common corporate finance tools and knowledge as applied within the context of considering, developing and executing M&A transactions. Participants will apply insights and skills taken from previous courses in finance.

The course includes negotiation within the context of M&A.

Case studies are used extensively throughout the course? including the use of current or recent transactions involving listed companies.

The course is a mixture of presentations, class discussions, case studies and group exercises all with an emphasis on the practical applications of corporate finance skills and knowledge within the context of M&A.

Business School","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5540 - Business Modelling","description":"

This course will equip you with the practical skills to design and structure decision-making models. Students will be presented with a design methodology and the associated modelling techniques necessary to build models that are clear to use, powerful in application and address specific needs.


The models may be financial models, decision-making models, costing models or operational models. Regardless of their purpose, the course will also equip you to visualise results in well-structured dashboards that adhere to the needs of C-suite professionals and organisational decision-makers.


The techniques covered will focus on Microsoft Excel and would benefit anyone who wishes to better understand, build, analyse or maintain Excel-based models. Please note that this subject is taught with reference to Microsoft Excel in a Windows-based environment. This is a deliberate choice to reflect the reality that the modelling profession works almost exclusively in Microsoft Excel for Windows. Students who choose to take this subject with Apple-based Excel environments should be aware that many instructions involve detailed key strokes and Ribbon references that may not easily translate to an Apple environment.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5541 - Advanced Topics in Management","description":"

This course concentrates on selected emergent topics, issues and debates in the areas of Management and Business. It will survey a range of established and emerging trends in theory and research within management literature. Specifically, the course aims to cover key topics in the fields of management, leadership, organisational behaviour, organisation theory, international business, innovation, entrepreneurship, marketing, economics and strategy.


The aim of this course is to offer the opportunity to develop insights about contemporary Management and Business field theories and models. Students will review and critically discuss major theories, frameworks and case studies, and how they relate to individuals, groups, and organisations. contentlets.description:
This course concentrates on selected emergent topics, issues and debates in the areas of Management and Business. It will survey a range of established and emerging trends in theory and research within management literature. Specifically, the course aims to cover key topics in the fields of management, leadership, organisational behaviour, organisation theory, international business, innovation, entrepreneurship, marketing, economics and strategy.

The aim of this course is to offer the opportunity to develop insights about contemporary Management and Business field theories and models. Students will review and critically discuss major theories, frameworks and case studies, and how they relate to individuals, groups, and organisations. The course will assist students to compare, critique, and contribute to theoretical debate and to develop knowledge and understanding for future practical application.
contentlets.title: Advanced Topics in Management

contentlets.description: Prior to the arrival of the first European settlers and convicts in January 1788, contemporary political and business leaders perceived Australia as terra nullis – the empty land. Today, it is often characterized as the “land down under”: remote, but somehow familiar. This course presents students with an introduction to Australia as a complex economy and society built from successive waves of migration, foreign investment and local innovation. Within 100 years of that first, fledgling penal colony, Australia was home to the world’s wealthiest city (in per capita income terms) and, more recently, Australia has uniquely enjoyed more than two decades of uninterrupted economic growth, while other OECD countries have suffered recession in the wake of the global financial crises. During the same two decades, Australia’s geopolitical focus has shifted from its historical and cultural ties to Britain and Europe to Asia. The course considers Australia’s economic and political systems, the nature of government-business relations, Australian cultural norms, and what they mean for doing business in Australia and Australia as a ‘gateway to Asia’.   The course flexibly blends input from instructors with input from students, mini-cases and exercises, facilitated discussions, unique experiential learning opportunities and corporate site visits to inform students how to operate Australia’s economic, political and social landscape and to challenge them to understand the ‘land down under’ as a place to do business.
contentlets.title: Doing Business in Australia

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5585 - Individual Study in Management","description":"

Students may select a business topic to research under the supervision of an AGSM faculty member.


This one-to-one working arrangement allows the student to carry out in depth analysis of a topic relevant to his or her career aspirations.


A student may do an ISM if:


  • the student has a good academic record (with a minimum high credit average);
  • the study is in an area relevant to management;
  • the topic is in some way relevant to the student's career aspirations;
  • a suitable AGSM faculty member, or members, are available to supervise the work.

contentlets.description:
Students may select a business topic to research under the supervision of an AGSM faculty member.

This one-to-one working arrangement allows the student to carry out in depth analysis of a topic relevant to his or her career aspirations.

A student may do an ISM if:

  • the student has a good academic record (with a minimum high credit average);
  • the study is in an area relevant to management;
  • the topic is in some way relevant to the student's career aspirations;
  • a suitable AGSM faculty member, or members, are available to supervise the work.
contentlets.title: Individual Study in Management

Strategic Consulting Projects offer MBA candidates who have completed their core courses real opportunities in businesses. Teams collaborate with corporate managers and AGSM Academics to apply conceptual frameworks and global best practice to management challenges, finding practical solutions for companies. Students are supported in the completion of their project by an Academic Supervisor and the Program Office.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5685 - Crisis and Issues Leadership","description":"

This is an applied leadership course, contextualised to the contemporary environment. Delivery options include online, face-to-face (classroom) and experiential components. It will be offered as an elective course in the Full-time MBA Program.


We will provide students with a fundamental understanding of the complex nature of the contemporary business environment and the importance of strong, decisive and integrated leadership in times of crisis.


Learnings are brought to life through the use of contemporary case studies, with the course culminating in an experiential component in which students will be given the responsibilities of a fictitious company’s Crisis Management Team during a critical incident. Assimilation of course content will be put to the test in this simulation as participants deal with the emerging situation. The situation will require rapid decision-making and confident leadership in an ambiguous and rapidly evolving information environment, as well as the ability to interface appropriately with a wide variety of stakeholders – including confronting the media, employees, suppliers and the families of impacted people. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d29f7f711b12f450d5fb0fabdc4bcba8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Experiential Component","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will become the Crisis Management Team of a fictitious company facing an emerging crisis. In this capacity, they will be required to assimilate information inputs from multiple disparate sources and develop situational understanding within this ambiguous and rapidly emerging information environment in order to make decisions and communicate. Concurrently, the team will need to prioritise and satisfy demands from a wide range of stakeholders, ranging from the company board, to social and traditional media outlets, regulatory bodies, employees and the families of impacted personnel. ‘Hot’ debriefs will be conducted at key points throughout the activity to ensure that learnings are captured, discussed and shared.

Each student will be provided an opportunity to act in a leadership position, and they will be assessed upon this as well as their participation as team members. Assessment criteria will be based on their ability to apply the information taught during the program as both a team member and a leader.

Feedback will be a combination of verbal and written, primarily verbal for this assessment and given at the end of the experiential component.

Students will become the Crisis Management Team of a fictitious company facing an emerging crisis. In this capacity, they will be required to assimilate information inputs from multiple disparate sources and develop situational understanding within this ambiguous and rapidly emerging information environment in order to make decisions and communicate. Concurrently, the team will need to prioritise and satisfy demands from a wide range of stakeholders, ranging from the company board, to social and traditional media outlets, regulatory bodies, employees and the families of impacted personnel. ‘Hot’ debriefs will be conducted at key points throughout the activity to ensure that learnings are captured, discussed and shared.

Each student will be provided an opportunity to act in a leadership position, and they will be assessed upon this as well as their participation as team members. Assessment criteria will be based on their ability to apply the information taught during the program as both a team member and a leader.

Feedback will be a combination of verbal and written, primarily verbal for this assessment and given at the end of the experiential component.

contentlets.keywords: management,leadership,crisis,crisis management,issues leadership,crisis leadership,applied leadership,issues management,integrated leadership,situational awareness
contentlets.description:
This is an applied leadership course, contextualised to the contemporary environment. Delivery options include online, face-to-face (classroom) and experiential components. It will be offered as an elective course in the Full-time MBA Program.

We will provide students with a fundamental understanding of the complex nature of the contemporary business environment and the importance of strong, decisive and integrated leadership in times of crisis.

Learnings are brought to life through the use of contemporary case studies, with the course culminating in an experiential component in which students will be given the responsibilities of a fictitious company’s Crisis Management Team during a critical incident. Assimilation of course content will be put to the test in this simulation as participants deal with the emerging situation. The situation will require rapid decision-making and confident leadership in an ambiguous and rapidly evolving information environment, as well as the ability to interface appropriately with a wide variety of stakeholders – including confronting the media, employees, suppliers and the families of impacted people.
contentlets.title: Crisis and Issues Leadership

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT7497 - Growth","description":"

Congratulations on successfully completing the first half of the Executive Agenda Year!


The aim of MNGT7497 Growth is for you to develop strategic thinking and analysis skills that you will apply in formulating effective growth strategies for your organisation. You will gain these skills through engaging in activities and assessments that help you develop in the areas of identifying, evaluating and planning the implementation of value-creating growth options. We will draw on your experiences, written case studies, published articles, book chapters, videos, podcasts, a live case study and simulations to help build your skills in these areas.


You will analyse a range of different growth options available to managers. Two primary paths for organisational growth involve: (a) expanding into new products/services and (b) expanding into new markets (i.e. geographic locations and customer segments).


Another important dimension to consider, together with the two primary paths, is resources. Organisations can be viewed as bundles of resources. Examples of resources are brand names, in-house knowledge of technology, skilled personnel, trade contracts, machinery, capital, efficient procedures, etc. As we will explore in the course, analysing the organisation from the resource perspective can help to identify new strategic growth options. Note that our use of the term 'Resources' includes capabilities and management systems.


Also, for each of the two expansion paths, there are several alternative vehicles for growth. An organisation can elect to grow organically by expanding the market share of its current business, innovating into new products/services, or opening greenfield sites in new geographic locations. Alternatively, an organisation may decide to grow through merger or acquisition. Finally, strategic partnerships or alliances represent yet another vehicle for growth arranged through long-term contracts/licences, equity stakes or joint ventures (JVs) between separate organisations. Many organisations employ all of these vehicles in their growth strategies.


In the course, we will discuss each of these paths and vehicles for growing organisations and evaluate options for growth in a variety of sectors and contexts. However, identifying attractive growth options does not automatically translate into success. Managers also need to successfully implement a growth strategy to make it work. An integrated growth strategy includes a plan for obtaining the capabilities needed to succeed in each growth option, the timing and phasing of each step involved to expand the organisation, and aligning the structure and systems for managing organisational growth.


A very important aspect of implementing an effective growth strategy entails identifying and thinking through the risks involved. There are substantial risks associated with growth strategies. A great deal of research shows that the expected economic benefits of diversifying into new products/services are often not captured, and that many mergers and acquisitions are failures. Similarly, international expansion often falls short of delivering the expected returns. However, this has not stopped managers from engaging in widespread diversification, implementing mergers and acquisitions, or expanding internationally in attmpts to fuel company growth.


Most of the medium and large Australian companies we read about in the business press every day have expanded beyond a single product or single market, and many have been involved in a merger or acquisition. In the course we will discuss how to limit risk by identifying growth options that leverage the existing strengths of the organisation, how to evaluate whether an organisation is the natural or best owner of a given business, and how to avoid paying too much for an acquisition.

The first assessment is composed of three small quizzes that act as an active learning tool to promote better recall and deeper learning. These are also used as a Readiness Assurance Test to assess your mastery of the course material prior to the four-day residential session.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"61e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961905","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"31e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961932","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4B : Participation in post-residential simulation","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"7","weighting":"5","description":"

Mergers and acquisitions are a key vehicle for implementing new growth options. Evidence from research shows that appropriately managing the integration process in the post-merger or post-acquisition stage is perhaps the most challenging aspect of any M&A. In order to gain experience with the integration process, students will engage in an online simulation of a merger between two retail banks. Unit 9 provides instructions for preparing for and playing the simulation

Details

Completing this assessment will require students to:

  1. individually complete the online simulation by Friday of Week 7. The simulation takes a little under two hours (if you do not stop the simulation).
  2. watch the debriefing video posted in Moodle by the Course Coordinator
  3. post short contribution(s) (200 words) to the Moodle course discussion synthesising the key lessons you learned from the simulation and any insights you can use in your own organisation. This discussion post is due in Week 7 by 11am Friday Sydney time.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"61e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"69e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961904","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c2e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961943","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4A : Participation during the four-day residential","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"6","weighting":"5","description":"

The four-day residential component of the course is designed to help students practise applying course concepts and tools so that they will be able to transfer course knowledge and skills beyond the classroom to real-world problems after the course is over. In order to accomplish this goal, the interpretations and varied experiences of every student participating in the residential sessions are critical. As students work on residential activities, they are encouraged to identify questions and insights that they can raise when those topics are brought to bear during the residential discussion sessions. Anything that puzzles students, or that they find particularly useful, or something that raises questions, might trigger particularly insightful discussions or revelations in other students. That is why openly asking questions and sharing with the rest of the class specific experiences make the residential sessions particularly (arguably uniquely) useful for all participants.

Details

Students should aim to make substantive contributions (informed by the course materials or by their professional or personal experiences) to raise the quality and depth of class discussions. While it is acceptable and expected that each student would have their own opinion, we expect all students to show respect towards others. The class facilitator will assess students’ contributions throughout the whole residential based primarily on the quality of these contributions rather than their quantity.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"61e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"69e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961904","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e5e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961915","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Individual Growth Strategy Paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"35","description":"

In this assessment, you are expected to formulate a recommended growth strategy for your own organisation or any other organisation you might have extensive knowledge about or ready access to information about. The recommended growth strategy must be different from any strategy or components of a strategy that you submitted for EAY1 or EAY2. This assessment is another opportunity to apply the concepts and lessons learned in the course to a real-world organisation, and is the same format and structure as the Live case growth strategy paper.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"61e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"61e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"61e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"61e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"65e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"69e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"69e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961905","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e5e848f5db9eb450595850d8f496191c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4C : Team participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"8","weighting":"10","description":"

Multiple activities during this course are performed through an active collaboration of a team of students. The expectation at the level of the MBA (Executive) program is that students are proactively engaged and consistently collaborate and even help overcome any challenges their team might face when trying to accomplish a particular objective. In other words, self-awareness, proactivity and leadership when engaging in teamwork are expected from students. In order to reward those students who consistently meet these expectations during each and every one of the team-based activities in this course, the teammates of each of the students participating in this course will have the opportunity to assess whether each of their team members has met these expectations.

Details

By the start of Week 9, you will receive a link to complete the online peer assessment survey for each member of your team. When completing the online peer assessment, please add in at least a brief comment for each team member on all three questions to justify your rating. Your ratings and comments for each team member will be anonymous, but will be shared with them (along with the ratings and comments from every other team member). Do NOT select the Not Applicable check box for any of the questions; they are all applicable! If you do not complete the online peer assessment, then your ratings on all three questions for all of your team members will be counted as zero and this will negatively impact your team members’ participation mark. Be sure to scroll down and answer all three questions on the online assessment; if you do not scroll down to the bottom you may miss the third question and the default ratings are zero (which will negatively impact your team members’ mark).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"61e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"69e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961904","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f5e848f5db9eb450595850d8f4961934","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Live Case Growth Strategy Paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

During the four-day residential, you will start developing a growth strategy for a real organisation. Early in the residential, a senior manager from the organisation will introduce and set up the live case study for us as a guest speaker. By the end of the residential, your team will present a recommended growth strategy for the organisation to achieve its growth objectives. The senior manager from the organisation will provide comments and suggestions during the presentations.

contentlets.description:
Congratulations on successfully completing the first half of the Executive Agenda Year!

The aim of MNGT7497 Growth is for you to develop strategic thinking and analysis skills that you will apply in formulating effective growth strategies for your organisation. You will gain these skills through engaging in activities and assessments that help you develop in the areas of identifying, evaluating and planning the implementation of value-creating growth options. We will draw on your experiences, written case studies, published articles, book chapters, videos, podcasts, a live case study and simulations to help build your skills in these areas.

You will analyse a range of different growth options available to managers. Two primary paths for organisational growth involve: (a) expanding into new products/services and (b) expanding into new markets (i.e. geographic locations and customer segments).

Another important dimension to consider, together with the two primary paths, is resources. Organisations can be viewed as bundles of resources. Examples of resources are brand names, in-house knowledge of technology, skilled personnel, trade contracts, machinery, capital, efficient procedures, etc. As we will explore in the course, analysing the organisation from the resource perspective can help to identify new strategic growth options. Note that our use of the term 'Resources' includes capabilities and management systems.

Also, for each of the two expansion paths, there are several alternative vehicles for growth. An organisation can elect to grow organically by expanding the market share of its current business, innovating into new products/services, or opening greenfield sites in new geographic locations. Alternatively, an organisation may decide to grow through merger or acquisition. Finally, strategic partnerships or alliances represent yet another vehicle for growth arranged through long-term contracts/licences, equity stakes or joint ventures (JVs) between separate organisations. Many organisations employ all of these vehicles in their growth strategies.

In the course, we will discuss each of these paths and vehicles for growing organisations and evaluate options for growth in a variety of sectors and contexts. However, identifying attractive growth options does not automatically translate into success. Managers also need to successfully implement a growth strategy to make it work. An integrated growth strategy includes a plan for obtaining the capabilities needed to succeed in each growth option, the timing and phasing of each step involved to expand the organisation, and aligning the structure and systems for managing organisational growth.

A very important aspect of implementing an effective growth strategy entails identifying and thinking through the risks involved. There are substantial risks associated with growth strategies. A great deal of research shows that the expected economic benefits of diversifying into new products/services are often not captured, and that many mergers and acquisitions are failures. Similarly, international expansion often falls short of delivering the expected returns. However, this has not stopped managers from engaging in widespread diversification, implementing mergers and acquisitions, or expanding internationally in attmpts to fuel company growth.

Most of the medium and large Australian companies we read about in the business press every day have expanded beyond a single product or single market, and many have been involved in a merger or acquisition. In the course we will discuss how to limit risk by identifying growth options that leverage the existing strengths of the organisation, how to evaluate whether an organisation is the natural or best owner of a given business, and how to avoid paying too much for an acquisition.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT7498 - Transformation","description":"

Transformation means dealing with the challenges of change and uncertainty, sensing, seizing and transforming. This requires critical thinking to deal with the frequent paradoxical choices in todays business environment where transformation is increasingly an ongoing activity rather than a once-in-a-career event. In this course students learn to accept and embrace uncertainty. You will build important skills and mindsets to lead organisational business model shifts and organisational transformation projects with confidence.


In a world besotted with disruption, globalisation and the digital economy, the concepts contained in MNGT7498 Transformation are of paramount importance to any leader looking to run a successful organisation over the next decade (and beyond). This course also provides an opportunity to re-calibrate your personal and professional transformation journey refining your path to success as you exit the program.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"applies_to_all","name":"Assessments"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Team Case Analysis and Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

As a group, your team will present an analysis and recommendation for an organisation during Day 4 of the Residential. This presentation will include an analysis of the current situation, a proposal for a new business model, and a recommended transformation strategy – supported by financial analysis.

Your team will self-select an organisation to investigate. However, to enhance cohort learning, the Class Facilitator will request that the teams select different organisations.

The preferred type of organisation to investigate is one that is experiencing serious performance deterioration or one that may wish to be proactive in anticipation of expected negative trends. In either case, the organisation will need to redesign its business model to meet current and future challenges. An alternative, with Class Facilitator approval, is to examine an organisation that needed a transformation but failed to implement one. What should they have done?

Importantly, in either approach you need to have access to top-level people in the organisation and to information on the organisation (see detail below).

The investigation will be similar to a consulting project where your team will be able to provide the results of your investigation to the participating organisation (this is a key benefit for them).

As a group, your team presented an analysis and recommendation for an organisation during the Residential. This presentation included an analysis of the current situation, a proposal for a new business model and a recommended transformation strategy.

In Assignment 2, as an individual, you are required to complete an evaluation of your peers’ teamwork. This assignment is compulsory.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"e0c9c879db9eb450595850d8f496192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e0c9c879db9eb450595850d8f496192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e8c9c879db9eb450595850d8f496192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"e8c9c879db9eb450595850d8f496192d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e8c9c879db9eb450595850d8f496192f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Transformation Project Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

There is a large amount of evidence that practising a newly learned skill is beneficial in both embedding and further developing knowledge. Thus, Assignment 3 is designed to allow practise in organisational transformation. The intent is for you to demonstrate that you can apply organisational transformation tools and frameworks to accomplish a transformation that is important, strategic or beyond your normal work requirements.

It is highly recommended that you begin planning for this assignment as early as possible! Transformation projects can frequently take weeks, months and sometimes years. Stronger assignments will capture more steps in the process.

You may create a new project in your organisation or team, you may create a new project in a social group, you may select a project in your organisation where you are a key player, or you may discuss other options with your Class Facilitator.

While our readings explore top-level organisational change, the tools and frameworks can be applied at any level, so you may select a project appropriate for your level in the organisation. In the rare case where you cannot create or find a transformation project, you may be allowed to: 1) assess a previous change process, or 2) analyse a situation where you were subject to a transformation and you can then explain how you responded to get things done (please discuss with your Class Facilitator). However, please note that these alternatives risk receiving a lower mark for the ‘demonstrate doing’ aspect of the assignment.

We have several readings about organisational transformation that will create the foundations for this assignment. Specifically, we expect the use of Kotter’s eight steps (either version) and tools to support each step from the other readings. These additional tools (also see Residential slides) will enable you to ensure that your recommendations are justified. Please see Units 3 and 4.

The activities that will be assessed for participation are as follows.

Checkpoint Conference Calls, Peer Evaluations and Discussion Forums during the 10-week session (excluding the Residential days) 10%:

You are required to submit team checkpoint reports, attend checkpoint conference calls and participate in discussion forums (major portion of the mark). This participation activity will be evaluated based on quality (not only quantity) of your contribution. See assessment criteria below.

Residential Participation 10%:

You will have the opportunity to actively participate in discussion during the Residential. Participation in such activity will be evaluated based on quality (not only quantity) of your contribution. See assessment criteria below.

You are also required to peer-assess the team case presentations.
